title-group.article-title: Adverse childhood experiences as predictors of alcohol and tobacco addiction risk among college students in Delhi-NCR, India

abstract.p: Substance use is a major public health concern, particularly among college students. Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACEs) have been shown to increase the risk of substance use in adulthood. Therefore, the present study aims to understand the impact of cumulative and domain-specific ACEs on alcohol and tobacco use, and associated addiction risks among college-going students in the Delhi-NCR, India. The study was conducted among 1813 college students from two universities in Delhi-NCR. Data on sociodemographic variables were collected using pre-tested and modified interview schedule. The WHO Alcohol, Smoking and Substance Involvement Screening Test (ASSIST) was used to assess alcohol and tobacco use and their addiction risk, while the ACEs were measured using ACE-International Questionnaire (ACE-IQ). Statistical analysis was performed using SPSS version 22.0. The findings revealed higher prevalence of alcohol and tobacco use, and addiction risk among the ACE exposed group than the unexposed group. Higher odds of use and addiction risk for alcohol, tobacco and combined substances were observed among ACE exposed individuals. Age, socioeconomic status, parental education status, and mother’s occupation were found to be significant predictors of substance use among both ACE exposed and unexposed groups. An early age of initiation of alcohol use was observed among those exposed to ACEs. Domain wise analysis revealed that ACEs related to household dysfunction were more consistently associated with the substance use, whereas those related to neglect and abuse were more strongly associated with addiction risk. Further, bullying was associated with substance use, whereas community and collective violence were more strongly associated with addiction risk to these substances. Overall, the study reveals the adverse effects of ACEs on alcohol and tobacco use, as well as addiction risk, among college students in Delhi-NCR, India. These findings highlight the urgent need to address ACEs in trauma-uninformed settings, which could help mitigate the burden of substance use, and also underscore the importance of integrating ACE-informed approaches into existing substance use prevention and intervention programs.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Substance use disorder (SUD) represents an emerging public health concern worldwide, leading to increased rates of morbidity and mortality, particularly among young adults1,2. Alcohol and tobacco are the two most common substances used in India, contributing to a heightened risk of various physical (hypertensions, dyslipidemia, diabetes, etc.), and mental health problems (depression, anxiety, suicide, hallucinations, etc.)3–5.

Young adults, particularly college going youth, exhibit a high prevalence of substance use2,6, making them a particularly vulnerable group for the development of SUDs. This developmental phase is marked by significant transitions, including a growing sense of independence, and exposure to stressors such as new living environment, peer pressure, unsupervised monetary expenditure, new social relationships, and academic pressure, all of which collectively heighten the risk of substance use in this group7. College-going youth, therefore, represent an important target group for early preventive interventions, which have the potential to not only reduce the immediate harm of substance use but also to limit progression to chronic addiction and associated health problems in future life.

Substance use has been reported to be driven by a range of sociodemographic, environmental, and biological factors1. Of these, Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACEs) are among the the most significant stressor, yet they remain under-recognized, particularly in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs)8. While ACEs have been extensively studied in Western countries, they have received comparatively less scientific attention in developing countries like India9,10.

ACEs refer to stressful or traumatic events, such as abuse, neglect, household dysfunction, or exposure to violence, that occur before the age of 18 years and can influence an individual’s health outcomes and well-being later in life11. Though research in western countries has well documented the association between ACEs and an increased risk of substance use6,8, evidence from LMICs is limited. The concept and perception of ACEs in India may differ from those in Western countries due to distinct socio-cultural norms9,10. In Indian societies, certain ACEs are often perceived as part of routine child-rearing norms, thereby contributing to trauma-uninformed practices10,12. For example, corporal punishment is widely viewed as a socially acceptable method to discipline and control children’s behaviour and remains a routine part of parenting13.

Previous studies have further reported that approximately 75% of mothers in rural India employed moderate verbal or psychological punishment (such as shouting, threatening physical harm, or withholding food); 76.5% reported using moderate physical punishment (such as slapping, pulling hair, or twisting ears); 49.1% of mothers used severe verbal or psychological measures (such as calling children names like “stupid” or “useless,” or threatening to send them away); and 42.3% used severe physical practices (such as hitting with a stick, hanging by the hands, or kicking) as disciplinary measures14.

Moreover, gendered dimensions of corporal punishment have also been reported, with punishment being disproportionately directed at girl children to make them more obedient and subservient15. Evidence from the literature suggests that Indian children are particularly vulnerable to psychological and physical abuse, often justified as a means of instilling respect for elders, discipline, or socialization13–15. Further studies have also reported that students who experienced corporal punishment were more vulnerable to depression, anxiety, and low resilience16, all of which are associated with substance use17,18. These practices, grounded in longstanding cultural norms and intergenerational beliefs, are associated with significant adverse health outcomes and warrant systematic recognition and culturally sensitive interventions.

Further, previous studies have considered the ten original ACE domains specified in the original ACE study11. However, recent research has suggested that original 10 ACE domains (household substance abuse, mental illness in households, incarcerated household member, parental separation or divorce, violence with mother or father, emotional neglect, physical neglect, emotional abuse, physical abuse and sexual abuse) may not sufficient to describe the childhood adversities19. Therefore, an advanced questionnaire which comprises three more ACE domains related to violence (bullying or peer violence, community violence and collective violence) along with 10 original ACE domains was developed by World Health Organization (WHO) (Adverse Childhood Experiences International Questionnaire; ACE-IQ)20. In LMICs, where violence is more common, inclusion of expanded ACE domains is necessary to elucidate the impact of cumulative and domain wise ACEs on substance use.

Considering these research gaps, the heightened vulnerability of college-going students, and their suitability for early intervention, the present study investigates both the cumulative and domain-specific associations between ACE exposure and the use and addiction risk of alcohol and tobacco among college-going students in Delhi-National Capital Region (NCR), India.

sec.title: Study design, area and participants
sec.p: The present cross-sectional study is part of a larger ACE cohort study conducted among 1843 university students aged 18 to 25 years, residing in the Delhi-NCR region. The sample size for the present study was calculated to be 1786. After excluding individuals with missing data on use and addiction risk to alcohol and tobacco, a total of 1813 participants were included in the present study.

sec.title: Sample size calculation
sec.p: The sample size was calculated using G*Power version 3.1.9.7 software. A model with a single binary predictor X (Emotional Abuse = No or Yes) was considered to calculate the sample size21. The effect size (odds ratio), representing the odds of ever tobacco use among individuals who experienced emotional abuse, was taken as 1.5922. The event rate under null hypothesis (H₀), indicating the prevalence of tobacco use in the general population, was taken as 0.25723. Additionally, X parm π, representing the proportion of individuals in the exposed (emotional abuse) category out of the total population, was taken as 0.39812. The α error probability was set at 0.05, and power (1 – β error probability) at 0.80. An R2 value of 0.192 (from preliminary logistic regression analysis conducted on the available dataset) was entered to account for the effect of other covariates in the model. Based on these parameters, the minimum required sample size was calculated to be 893. Since the sample was collected from different colleges and departments of University of Delhi and Amity University, a design effect of 2 was applied to account for potential clustering within educational settings. Therefore, the final adjusted sample size was calculated to be 1786.

Participants were recruited from various colleges and departments of the University of Delhi, Delhi and Amity University, Noida. Prior to the commencement of fieldwork, all necessary approvals were obtained from the respective authorities of the concerned colleges and departments. Students were informed about the objectives of the study, and participation was entirely voluntary. Written informed consent was obtained from each participant prior to their recruitment. Of the 1843 participants, the present study includes 1813 individuals (68.5% females) with complete data on alcohol and tobacco use and addiction risk. Participants with self-reported chronic physical or mental health conditions, pregnant and lactating mothers, and individuals on long-term medication were excluded from the study as their existing health conditions, medications, or therapeutic interventions could influence the observed relationship between ACEs and substance use.

The ethical clearance for the present study was obtained from Departmental Ethics Committee of Department of Anthropology, University of Delhi (Approval number: Ref. No. anth/2022-23/532, and Ref. No. anth/2022-23/14).

sec.title: Data collection
sec.p: Data pertaining to sociodemographic variables [age, sex, education, social category, family type, number of brothers, number of sisters, birth order, mother’s education, father’s education, mother’s occupation (housewives, in business, and in service), and father’s occupation] were collected using pre-tested and modified interview schedule through face-to-face interactions.

sec.title: Socio-economic status
sec.p:
Modified Kuppuswamy scale was used to assess socioeconomic status (SES)24. It considers the education, and occupation of the head of the family, and family income to estimate SES and generates a numerical score on a scale of 0–2924. The categorization was as follows24:
Lower socio-economic class—Score of 10 or below.
Lowe middle socio-economic class—Score of 11–15.
Upper middle socio-economic class—Score of 16–25.
Upper socio-economic class—Score of 26–29.

sec.title: Adverse childhood experiences
sec.p: The WHO Adverse Childhood Experiences International Questionnaire (ACE-IQ)-Frequency Version was used to measure ACEs20. The ACE-IQ considers 10 original ACE domains (household member drug use, household member with mental illness, household incarcerated member, parental separation/death/divorce, household violence, emotional neglect, physical neglect, sexual abuse, physical abuse, emotional abuse) and three extended domains (bullying, community violence and collective violence)19,20. Depending on exposure to ACEs, scoring was performed on a scale of 0 to 13, with higher scores indicating exposure to multiple ACEs. Participants were alienated into five categories (0 ACE; 1 ACE, 2 ACEs, 3 ACEs and ≥ 4 ACEs) based on scores for exposure to ACEs9. The ACE-IQ instrument employs a mixed-format response system, incorporating both binary (“Yes”/“No”) items and frequency-based scales such as "Never," "Once," "A few times," and “Many times”20. Given this combination of response formats, McDonald’s Omega was used to assess internal consistency, yielding a reliability coefficient of 0.822 (Cronbach’s alpha = 0.783).

sec.title: Use and addiction risk to alcohol and tobacco
sec.p: The WHO Alcohol, Smoking, and Substance Involvement Screening Tool (ASSIST) was used to assess the use and addiction risk of tobacco and alcohol25. This tool evaluates the usage and addiction risk of substances such as alcohol, tobacco, cannabis, cocaine, amphetamines, inhalants, sedatives, opioids, hallucinogens, and other drugs. Each substance is assigned a risk score, which is categorized into ‘no risk’, ‘moderate risk’ and 'high risk. ASSIST consist of 8 items , item 1 assesses the lifetime use of substances; item 2 determines the frequency of substance use in past three months; item 3 asks about the frequency of strong urges to use substances in last three months; item 4 assesses the frequency of experiencing problems (social, health, financial) due to substance use in last three months; item 5 determines the frequency of problem in performing responsibilities due to substance use in past three months; item 6 asks if people expressed concern about their substance use; item 7 asks whether the individual has ever tried to cut down or stop use of a substance and failed in that attempt; and last item captures the data on the use of injection for taking drugs. Based on these questions, the ASSIST determines a score for each substance individually.

On the basis of these scores, the risk of substance addiction is categorized as no risk, moderate risk, or high risk. The cutoffs for addiction risk for alcohol and tobacco are as follows25:
Alcohol: Scores 0–10 indicated no risk, 11–26 signified moderate risk, and ≥ 27 or higher represented high risk.
Tobacco: Scores 0–3 indicated no risk, 4–26 signified moderate risk, and ≥ 27 indicated high risk.

The WHO ASSIST includes both binary (yes/no) and frequency-based response that assess the use and addiction risk behaviours for different substances. Therefore, the internal consistency of the ASSIST subscales was evaluated using both McDonald’s Omega and Cronbach’s alpha. Regarding the alcohol subscale, Mc Donald’s Omega was observed to be 0.838 and Cronbach’s alpha was 0.811, indicating good reliability. The tobacco subscale showed good and reliable internal consistency, with a McDonald’s Omega of 0.850 and Cronbach’s alpha of 0.822.
Individuals falling under the moderate- and high-risk categories were combined together in the category of addiction risk26.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Statistical analysis was conducted using SPSS version 22.0. Missing data were randomly distributed and were handled using pairwise deletion. Chi-square test was performed to examine differences in the distribution of ever users and those at addiction risk for alcohol and tobacco across sociodemographic categories, stratified by ACE exposure, as well as across ACE categories (ranging from 0 to ≥ 4). Multivariable regression analyses were conducted to assess the associations (odds ratio with 95% confidence interval) between sociodemographic variables and the use and addiction risk of alcohol and tobacco in ACE exposed and unexposed groups. Further, multivariable regression analyses were used to understand the associations (odds ratio [OR] with 95% confidence interval [CI]) between exposure to ACEs (both cumulative and domain-wise) and the use and addiction risk of alcohol, tobacco, and combined substances. In the analysis of combined substances use/addiction risk, individuals were categorized into three groups: those who had never used alcohol or tobacco, those who had used either alcohol or tobacco, and those who had used both substances. Similarly, combined risk was classified into three groups: individuals at addiction risk for neither substance, for either alcohol or tobacco use, and for both substances.

All regression models were adjusted for age, sex, education, and SES, based on both theoretical and empirical justifications, as these are well-established confounders in substance use research27,28. A p-value of ≤ 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

sec.title: General characteristics of the study sample
sec.p: General characteristics of the study sample are presented in Supplementary Table 1. In the study sample, 50.1% of participants were below 20 years of age, 68.5% were females, 64% belonged to unreserved category, 84.7% were students of undergraduate courses, 79.9% lived in a nuclear family, 25.1% were not having a brother, 9.4% were not having a sister, and 52% were the eldest child. Regarding parental education, occupation and SES, 49% of participants had mothers with college education, 57% had fathers with college education, 79.6% had mothers who were housewives, 48.6% had fathers in service, and 40.7% belongs to upper-middle class (Supplementary Table 1).

sec.title: Prevalence and sociodemographic correlates of alcohol use, tobacco use and their addiction risk in ACE exposed and unexposed groups
sec.p: The prevalence of ever users of alcohol and tobacco was higher in the ACE-exposed group (28.9% and 17.5%, respectively) compared to the ACE-unexposed group (18.6% and 8.2%, respectively). A similar trend was observed for addiction risk, with higher prevalence among ACE-exposed individuals for both alcohol (4.7%) and tobacco (11.2%) than among their ACE-unexposed counterparts (alcohol addiction risk = 2% and tobacco addiction risk = 4.8%) (Supplementary Tables 2 and 3).

Adjusted logistic regression analysis identified age, mother’s occupation, and socio-economic status as the significant common predictors for alcohol use in both ACE exposed and unexposed groups (Table 1). In both ACE exposed and unexposed groups, individuals with mothers in business were observed to have higher odds of alcohol use (higher magnitude among ACE unexposed individuals) than those whose mothers were housewives. Compared to upper class, those belonging to upper-middle, lower middle and lower socio-economic class were observed to have reduced odds of alcohol use. Further, among ACE exposed individuals, the increased risk for alcohol use was observed even in the younger age group (20–21 years and above years in ACE exposed vs 22–23 years and above in ACE unexposed), suggesting an early initiation of alcohol use among them.Table 1

Interestingly, those having brothers, lower parental educational status, and belonging to Other Backward Classes (OBC) were observed to have lower odds for alcohol use than their respective counterparts, particularly in ACE exposed group. Coming to alcohol addiction risk, age group 22–23 years (with 18–19 as the reference) and being the younger child (with the eldest as the reference; associated with reduced risk) were found to be significant predictors of addiction risk among ACE exposed group, whereas father’s occupation (others, with service as the reference) was observed to be a significant predictor in the ACE unexposed group (Table 1).

Regarding tobacco use and its addiction risk, age was the only significant predictor common to both ACE exposed and unexposed groups, with a higher degree of odds among ACE unexposed individuals. In ACE unexposed group, those having a brother (with no brothers as the reference) was observed to have reduced odds for tobacco use, whereas individuals with mothers in business (with housewives as the reference) were found to have higher odds for tobacco use. In ACE exposed group, females (vs. males), individuals from the OBC category (vs. unreserved [UR]), those with lower parental education (6–12 years vs. college education), and participants from upper-middle SES, middle SES, and lower SES (vs. upper SES) were observed to have significantly reduced odds of both tobacco use and addiction risk (Table 2). Further, individuals from Scheduled Caste (SC) category (vs. UR), were observed to have the higher odds of tobacco addiction risk in ACE unexposed group.Table 2

sec.title: Prevalence of alcohol use, tobacco use, combined use of alcohol and tobacco, and their addiction risk across ACE categories (0–≥ 4 ACEs)
sec.p:
A significant increase in the proportion of ever alcohol users, those at risk of alcohol addiction, ever tobacco users and those at risk of tobacco addiction was observed across 0 to ≥ 4 ACEs categories (dose-response relationship) (Table 3). Similarly, the proportion of combined users (using both alcohol and tobacco), as well as those at combined risk of addiction to both substances, increased progressively across ACE categories from 0 to ≥4 (Table 3).Table 3

sec.title: Odds of alcohol use, tobacco use, combined use of alcohol and tobacco, and their addiction risk across ACE categories
sec.p:
With 0 ACE as reference, an increase in the odds of alcohol use, alcohol addiction risk, tobacco use, and tobacco addiction risk (except in 2 ACEs category) was observed from 1 to ≥ 4 ACE categories (Table 4). The significantly higher odds of the combined substance use [either alcohol/tobacco in ≥ 4 ACEs (OR: 2.655, 95% CI: 1.727–4.082), both alcohol and tobacco in 2 to ≥ 4 ACEs (OR: 2.177, 95% CI: 1.275–3.719 to OR: 5.799, 95% CI: 3.475–9.677)], as well as the combined risk of addiction to both substances [either alcohol/tobacco across ACEs (OR: 2.438, 95% CI: 1.288–4.614 to OR: 5.135, 95% CI: 2.721–9.691), both alcohol and tobacco in 3 and ≥ 4 ACEs (OR: 3.447, 95% CI: 1.267–9.378 and OR: 4.027, 95% CI: 1.593–10.181)] were observed across various ACE exposed categories. Individuals who were exposed to 4 or more ACEs, were observed to have the highest odds of using and becoming addicted to both substances [Alcohol use (OR: 3.442, 95% CI: 2.373–4.993); alcohol addiction risk (OR: 3.972, 95% CI: 1.786–8.833); tobacco use (OR: 4.267, 95% CI: 2.678–6.797); tobacco addiction risk (OR: 4.386, 95% CI: 2.472–7.783)]. sec.title: Prevalence of alcohol use, tobacco use, combined use of alcohol and tobacco, and their addiction risk across ACE domains
Odds of alcohol use, tobacco use, combined use of alcohol and tobacco, and their addiction risk across ACE domains
sec.p: Coming to tobacco addiction risk, higher odds were observed among those who experienced living with household member with mental illness. Moreover, two ACE domains related to household dysfunction (household drug abuse and household member with mental illness) were found to increase the odds of combined addiction risk (either alcohol/tobacco). All domains of abuse and community violence were found to be associated with higher odds of both use and addiction risk of alcohol, tobacco and combined substances. Individuals who were exposed to ACE domains related to neglect, and collective violence, were observed to have higher odds of alcohol, tobacco, and combined substances (either alcohol/tobacco or both) addiction risk. Bullying was found to be associated with increased odds of substance use (alcohol, tobacco and combined) (Table 6).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Studies have documented that individuals exposed to ACEs are more likely to engage in alcohol and tobacco use, and experience a heightened risk of addiction as compared to ACE unexposed individuals29–31. Consistent with these findings, the present study also revealed higher prevalence of ever alcohol and tobacco use, as well as addiction risks among ACE exposed individuals in comparison to their unexposed counterparts. Alternatively, studies have consistently reported higher prevalence of ACEs among individuals who use or are addicted to substances, including alcohol, tobacco, cannabis, illicit drugs etc.32,33.

The present study also suggested an earlier age of initiation for alcohol use, as well as a higher risk of addiction at a young age among ACE exposed individuals compared to their unexposed counterparts. Research from western countries has similarly documented a positive correlation between ACEs and early initiation of alcohol and tobacco use34,35. Further, studies have identified ACE exposure as a significant predictor of early initiation of substance use, including alcohol, tobacco, and cannabis36.

Notably, familial factors such as having brothers, and belonging to middle and lower socio-economic classes were associated with reduced odds of alcohol use, whereas mothers in business was associated with higher odds of alcohol use in both groups (ACE exposed and ACE unexposed). These factors can influence the family environment. For instance, brothers can act as a source of emotional support, help release family pressure, and reduce feelings of loneliness, which can impact an individual’s stress coping abilities, potentially reducing the risk of various mental health problems like depression, anxiety, SUD. Further, mothers in business may have less time for parental monitoring, which may lead to reduced child supervision and increased risk of substance use among their children37.

Further, a plausible reason for the reduced odds of alcohol use among individuals from middle and lower SES in both ACE exposed and unexposed groups, may be the limited access to resources and money, making substances inaccessible to them and reducing their use at younger ages. Recent study have reported a positive relationship between high family SES and alcohol use and intoxication, possibly due to greater financial accessibility to alcohol and other substances38,39. However, conflicting evidence exists, as studies from Europe, Switzerland, and India have also identified lower SES as a risk factor for substance use38,40. Previous studies have documented low-SES neighbourhoods as a key predictor of substance use38,40,41. Moreover, existing literature suggests that low-SES neighbourhoodsare associated with a lack of recreational activities and increased exposure to illegal activities like dealing of illicit substances, which may heightened the risk of substance use39,41. Research on the relationship between SES and substance use highlights its complexity. Some studies suggest that higher SES may be associated with increased alcohol and illicit drug use42, while others indicate that lower SES is linked to a greater likelihood of engaging in multiple substance use behaviors. The association also appears to differ by substance type, with lower SES correlating with higher tobacco use and higher SES with more frequent alcohol consumption43.

Female gender was found to be associated with reduced odds of tobacco use and addiction, particularly among the ACE-exposed group. Previous studies have consistently reported that men have higher odds of access to and lifetime use of substance use compared to women44. Epidemiological studies from India have also documented the prevalence of illicit substances such as cannabis, opioids, and cocaine to be significantly lower among females than males45. A plausible reason behind this observation may be that, in developing countries like India, societal norms often discourage substance use among females more strongly than males, and they typically have limited access to substances like tobacco, thereby reducing their likelihood of using it as a stress-coping mechanism.

However, this gendered pattern may not apply uniformly across all substance types. It may differ for other illicit substances, as well as for those that are perceived as medically sanctioned, such as anxiolytics in different eco-cultural settings. A recent study showed that female college students in Spain reported higher non-prescription anxiolytic use than their male counterparts46. These findings underscore the importance of recognizing gendered substance use patterns, shaped by cultural norms and also by the nature and perceived legitimacy of the substance. In the Indian context, this highlights the need for future research to examine gender-specific trends across a broader range of substances to better inform targeted and substance-specific prevention strategies.

Factors such as number of brothers, mother’s occupation, and SES were significant predictors of substance use in both ACE exposed and unexposed group, with stronger odds observed in ACE unexposed group. Nevertheless, ACE exposed individuals had a higher overall risk of substance use. This observation suggests that the high risk of substance use and associated addiction risk among ACE exposed individual may be primarily attributable to the biological and behavioural alterations caused by ACEs.

Further, parental education was found to be a significant predictor of alcohol and tobacco use among ACE exposed group only. A few studies have suggested that higher parental education may be linked with increased smoking and drinking among young adults47.

In this study, lower parental education was associated with reduced odds of substance use and addiction risk, whereas mothers in business were associated with higher odds of substance use. Therefore, intervention strategies should emphasize the importance of balancing family responsibilities with career pursuits. Promoting supportive work environments that offer flexibility to working parents can help ensure quality time with children, thereby fostering emotional well-being and serving as a protective factor against substance use.

Research over last two decades has established a dose–response relationship between ACE exposure and SUD, particularly in western countries6. The present study revealed a significant dose–response relationship between ACE exposure levels andsubstance use prevalence and associated addiction risk. Further, adjusted logistic regression model also suggested significantly increased odds of alcohol use, tobacco use, combined use (either alcohol/tobacco or both) and associated addiction risk among individuals who experienced 3 and ≥ 4 ACEs. Only a few studies thus far have explored the relationship between ACE exposure and mental health outcomes (depression, anxiety, stress, SUD, etc.) in Indian context9,12. ACEs appear to be a universal predictor of SUD across populations6,31,48.

Interestingly, the odds for tobacco use, combined use and associated addiction risks were higher compared to alcohol at every level of ACE exposure. This may be attributed to easy availability, and low cost of tobacco. In India, alcohol and tobacco use is, in general, associated with social stigma, though the degree of stigma varies across cultural and gendered contexts. In some Indian communities, smoking tobacco has been accepted as a cultural practice47, making it more socially acceptable in such communities. In contrast, alcohol has a greater degree of social stigma. Alcohol use may be considered as a deviation from cultural modesty, especially for women. Further, tobacco use is often associated with youth slang, with flavoured hookah gaining popularity among college-going youth as a means of attracting peer attention49.

Despite the breadth of research exploring the relationship between ACE exposure and SUD, the exact mechanisms behind this association are not fully understood. However, brain and behaviour both are known to be affected by ACE exposure and SUD31. Therefore, the complex interplay of two plausible sets of pathways may explain the contribution of ACEs to increased risk of SUD. The two sets of pathways are biological pathways involving dysregulation of neurological and hormonal systems and socio-behavioural pathways involving behavioural problems resulting in adoption of maladaptive coping strategies31.

ACEs are known to impact brain development, which may results in altered brain structure, and impaired communication between prefrontal cortex and brain reward centres, in a way that enhance the reward value of substance use50. Studies have reported that changes induced by early life stress in the brain are similar to the changes observed in the brain of patients with SUD51,52.

Further, the chronic exposure to toxic stress due to childhood adversities results in dysregulation of Hypothalamic–Pituitary–Adrenal (HPA) axis, oxytocin system, endocrine system, and immune system leading to an increased risk of SUD36,37,53,54. Literature has reported mixed findings, suggesting that HPA axis dysregulation, both hypo- and-hyperactivity, can act as a biomarker of substance use and addiction54. Previous studies have also reported that dysregulation of stress regulating and reward processing systems may result in blunt stress reactivity, leading to poor emotional regulation, risk taking behaviours, poor behavioural control and increased likelihood of SUD50,55,56.

Coming to socio-behavioural pathways, ACEs have been recognized as key factors in dysregulation of social functioning resulting in social isolation, loneliness, difficulty in developing relationships with peers due to lack of trust, and poor emotional regulation57. To overcome these negative emotions, individuals start getting involved in risk taking behaviours and adopting maladaptive coping mechanisms, of which substance use is among the most common ones in adolescents and young adults6. Further, ACEs are recognized as significant contributors to both internalizing (e.g., depression, anxiety, bipolar disorder) and externalizing (e.g., aggression, impulsivity) behavioural problems, which often precede substance use and later manifest as addiction58,59.
Both biological and behavioural pathways interact in a complex, bidirectional manner to shape an individual’s vulnerability to SUD, particularly among those exposed to ACEs.

Delving into ACE domain-wise analysis, the pattern of associations revealed that family-level AECs and bullying were primarily associated with the use of alcohol, tobacco and their combined use, whereas abuse, neglect and violence were more strongly and consistently associated with the addiction risks for these substances (alcohol/tobacco/combined).

It can be argued that ACEs at family-level affect the child through shared family stress, and the burden is shared by the whole family rather than the child individually9. The toxic stress attributable to these family-level ACEs, incumbers the stress coping mechanism of an individual leading to increased risk of alcohol or tobacco use. However, the support offered by relatives and friends during family problems act as a protective buffer, preventing them from progressing toward addiction by providing emotional stability. Interestingly, having household member with alcohol/drug use problem was observed to increase the risk for substance use,but not addiction. Similar to the findings of the present study, existing scientific literature has consistently identified parental substance use as a significant predictor of substance use among adolescents60. Studies further suggest that the development of individual coping skills and living in a positive family environment may serve as protective buffers for individuals exposed to substance use within the household60. The study highlights that an integrated framework, drawing from both ecological and resilience theories, may help mitigate the intergenerational transmission of substance use.

Family environment can play a dual role, i.e., it can be a risk factor when parental substance use is present, but it can also be a source of resilience and protection. Protective family characteristics such as strong emotional bonding, consistent parental monitoring (especially maternal), and overall family cohesion have been shown to reduce the likelihood of substance use initiation, even among children exposed to substance use within the household60. These positive familial influences may act as a buffer against the adverse effects of parental substance use60. In contrast, peer influence, particularly close relationships with friends who consume substances such as alcohol, tobacco, or cocaine, has been identified as a significant risk factor, reinforcing the role of social context in shaping youth substance use behaviour61,62.

Moreover, previous studies have reported an inverse relationship between parental drug use and the child’s subsequent drug addiction, as observing the negative consequences of substance use may protect the child through vicarious reinforcement6,63.

On the other hand, individual-level ACEs, such as abuse, neglect, and bullying, may affect the individual directly leading to self-doubts, emotional turmoil, social isolation and development of externalizing and internalizing behaviours, which are well recognized risk factors for use and addiction risks of alcohol, tobacco, and other illicit drugs64,65. Moreover, abuse and neglect are associated with the social stigma, which often prevents individuals from discussing their experiences with others and seeking emotional supports, thereby intensifying their emotional distress66. To cope up with the stress associated with childhood maltreatment, individuals often begin using alcohol/tobacco and, their frequent consumption make them addicted to these psychoactive substances.

Although, studies have documented a robust association between emotional neglect and risk of SUDs 67,68, the present study revealed the impact of both emotional and physical neglect in increasing the addiction risk of studied substances. This may be attributed to the high prevalence of neglect in developing countries where low socio-economic settings are more common69. Further, in India, neglect is more common among female children as compared to male children, and in the present study, females constituted 68.5% of studied participants, which may be a plausible reason for physical neglect being a significant predictor of addiction risk. The variations in the association between domains of childhood neglect and substance use and addiction risk suggest that the magnitude of the negative consequences of childhood neglect in later life may be population- and culture-specific.

Further community and collective violence were found to be associated with increased likelihood of SUDs70. Violence in any form whether interpersonal or structural are strongly linked to adverse mental health outcomes, including substance use. Studies have reported the association between violence and low socio-economic settings71. Since such exposures are often more prevalent in low- and middle-income contexts, overlooking these domains may result in an incomplete understanding of ACEs and their consequences. Findings of this study underscore the importance of expanding the scope of ACE assessment beyond the original domains to include culturally and contextually relevant adversities.

Studies have reported inconsistent associations between substance use and domains of household dysfunction in western countries6. Nevertheless, household dysfunction, community violence and collective violence have been found to be associated with an increased risk of SUD in the Indian context72. A vast body of literature has documented that childhood abuse of any type (physical, sexual, and emotional) is consistently and strongly associated with increased vulnerability to addiction in adulthood73–75.

These important findings highlight the urgent need to recognize ACEs as critical environmental stressors in the Indian context, where some of such early life adversities are often normalized as part of child-rearing. The study underscores the need for formulating trauma-informed strategies for ACE prevention and tailored interventions to reduce the burden of alcohol and tobacco use and their associated addiction risks in adult life. Building on this, future research should prioritize investigating the possibility of integrating ACE screening and mitigation strategies into existing substance use prevention programs. Incorporating a trauma-informed framework that accounts for the enduring effects of ACEs on substance use and addiction risk may not only enhance the effectiveness of prevention programs but also promote overall mental and physical well-being by addressing the broader health challenges associated with substance use and addiction. Further, the findings emphasize the importance of adopting differential SUD treatment approaches for individuals with and without ACE exposure.

The present study has certain limitations that should be mentioned. First, the sample included a disproportionately higher number of female participants than males; however, this was statistically addressed by adjusting all regression models for sex. Second, the participants were college-going youth recruited from two universities, which may limit the generalizability of the findings to the general population. The exclusion of individuals undergoing treatment for major health conditions, those on long-term medication, and pregnant or lactating women may also limit the generalizability of the findings. Despite these constraints, the relatively large sample size and the inclusion of students from diverse sociodemographic backgrounds, different social categories and socio-economic class enhance the representativeness and the generalizability of the findings to some extent. Nevertheless, considering India’s socio-cultural diversity future research should prioritize multi-sited studies spanning different eco-cultural zones to have a better understanding of the relationship between ACEs and substance use.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The present study revealed a dose-response relationship between ACEs and the use and addiction risk of alcohol, tobacco and their combined use among college-going students. Early initiation and higher addiction risk to alcohol were observed among those exposed to ACEs, making them more vulnerable to addiction as they age. Interestingly, family level ACEs and bullying were observed to increase the odds of ever use of alcohol and tobacco, whereas ACEs related to abuse, neglect and violence (community and collective) were more consistently and strongly associated with addiction risk for alcohol and tobacco. These findings underscore the importance of initiating ACE awareness and prevention programs at individual, institutional, and community levels, particularly in the Indian context, where some of such early life adversities are considered as a part of child rearing practices. It is equally imperative to integrate ACE screening and mitigation strategies into existing substance use prevention efforts, grounded in a trauma-informed framework that considers the cumulative impact of ACEs on substance use trajectories and associated physical and mental health outcomes. Moreover, treatment strategies for individuals with substance use disorders should be tailored based on their history of ACE exposure, as differential treatment approaches may yield better outcomes. Considering the cultural diversity across Indian populations, more research is warranted to explore the relationship between ACEs and substance use in culturally and population-specific contexts.
